answers.answer: Seriously, they are popping up all over the place. I had a c-section same scenario as you. I scheduled my second, it was much better than being in labor and then a C-section...

I see your point....I never want another c-section but my first one was becasue of an emergency (cord around the baby's neck 6 times). But if I have any more, I want to have the baby naturally. However, I am not sure it will ever happen because my first c-section was a very wide cut because they didn't want any pressure around his head when they pulled him out. It was a horrible experience and it really irritates me when people ask for them....if babies were meant to be born via c-section, then they would be!!!

i also can't believe anyone would elect to do a c-section. i was traumatized by it as well, and thought i would never do it again. of course, memories fade with time. i still get kinda upset everytime i look at that scar. it bothers me that i was cut through 3 layers. of course it was worth it, but if i often wish i didn't have to have one. i had one 4 weeks early due to preeclampsia. my dr said if we induced that early, i would most likely need a c-sec anyways, because the baby and my body were no where near ready. it turned out to be a good call- i was so sick by then, i couldn't even stay awake while waiting for the c-sec. my dr. does not do vbac due to risks, so i will have to have another. i dread the recovery.its remarkable that more than half of the people i know who had babies recently had to have c-sections. with one coworker they discovered placenta previa and she would have bled to death. with another the baby was thought to have serious problems. another also had severe preeclampsia. another had an almost 10 lb baby that just wouldn't fit after going through labor. another's baby's heartrate plummeted during labor because the cord was wrapped around her neck.  i hated my c-sec, but i am very greatful, since if it were not available, both my baby and i would have been at risk of dying. same for those other cases.

I have a feeling that a lot of docs are not comfortable with VBACS...it just seems if you have one c-section you have the rest by c-section also.  It is just probably the safest way.Unlike the other posters my c-section was amazingly good.  Had it due to a breech presentation which did not change with the external version (now the version I would not recommend doing again!).  Recovery was a breeze for me.  I have heard the second c-section is harder to recover from than the first though.  Best of luck!

I also had a surprise c-section b/c she was face up and wasn't budging after 24 hrs of labor, and I wasn't going past 4cm.  Mine wasn't that bad, other than the surprise of having one.  Recovery was okay, although 6 months later I still feel numb there and the scar is still bright red.  My doctor told me that he had cut in such a way that he would be comfortable doing a VBAC for my next one.  I haven't decided if that is the way I want to go or not.  Honestly, VBAC sort of scares me.

okay so i didn't realize there were risks involved with normal delivery after a c--section. I mean besides the chances of you having another one...what are they?Also I did hear that before dr. and c-sections and all that jazz I guess 1 in 5 women and babies died in child birth. YIKES!

TJ, I have a very  narrow pelvis also - and after my first attempt at delivering,  my doc said don't even bother trying again.    It's a disappointment,  I always thought of my self as kind of a Prairie Woman,  that I was tough and could do anything by myself,  but you're right - before C sections were common,  I'd be dead and so would my baby.The most important thing is a healthy baby - the rest is unimportant in the long run.

I do not like the sounds of the 2nd C-section recovery being worse than the first! My recovery was awful! I was in so much pain I could barely move!!! Had I not had a c-section right when I did, my son would be dead so I am very happy that I was able to save Ashtyn. But I was a little upset because I wanted to have the baby natural and I always told my mom that I would never have a c-section lol and now I will never be able to have a baby natural.

cheyenne- i can totally relate to your disappointment. i also had a very tough recovery- don't know why. i actually have a very high pain tolerance too, so i was surprised. i have heard from many people that the second was actually easier, so don't go into it assuming it will be worse.

I had two c-sections.  My doctor flat out refused to even consider trying VBAC (and I personally didn't even want to try, so was fine with that).  He said that he was involved in a VBAC study and more went wrong than right and it's not worth the risk involved in his opinion.  I had friends who cried foul, saying, "Forget him!  You need a home birth and I know a great doula!"  Uh...no thanks.  Not interested.The recovery both times was really not a big deal and I don't remember the second being any worse or better than my first one (10 years earlier).  The biggest difference I found was that I had no clue what to expect the first time, so I just went with the flow--they told me what to do and I did it and it really seemed like no big deal--but I knew what was going to happen the second time (prep for the spinal, tugging feeling, etc.) and I was a bit anxious the second time because of that.  But it went really well both times and I honestly had no problem with recovery either time.All the best to you!

question: I have one son who was in the posterior position while trying to deliver him. I was in labor for 4 days and hardly dialated and then when I did pushed for one hour while the dr. tried to turn him but he just wasn't coming and his heart rate started to decrease and i ran a temp and my blood pressure went way down so they took him c-section. This time around I asked my dr. if I could go naturally because I was under the assumption that it was just because Jace was turned the wrong way he wouldn't fit through. The Dr. said that that wasn't all, that my hip structure/or pelvis structure was too small to push him through and 90% chance that would happen again. I don't want ot take the risk of the baby getting hurt so c-section is fine with me but it seemed like he was so quick to say that I would have to have another one. Also how come he didn't tell me that before but all of a sudden he remembers it 1 1/2 years later? You just hear of so many people having c-sections now days you wonder if they all really need them.
title: do i really need a scheduled c-section???
